importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The mid-year report from Morningstar about the Active/Passive Barometer includes performance data up to June 2025, providing a critical benchmark for evaluating active vs. passive fund performance over a 10-year period.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The Morningstar Active/Passive Barometer report evaluates active fund performance over a 10-year period ending in June 2025, highlighting long-term underperformance of most active funds compared to passive index funds.
Morningstar's analysis shows that over a 20-year period, only 7.1% of large cap blend funds outperformed index funds, demonstrating a consistent trend of passive investing superiority across decades.

keyTakeAways: The KISS (Keep It Simple and Smart) investing strategy emphasizes simplicity and low-cost index funds over complex, actively managed funds.
Most actively managed funds fail to outperform their passive counterparts, with only 21% of active strategies surviving and beating passive funds over a 10-year period.
Over a 20-year span, only 7.1% of large cap blend funds outperform index funds, indicating that passive investing is more reliable and efficient.
Target-date retirement funds automatically adjust asset allocation based on age and retirement date, offering a hands-off, diversified approach ideal for most individuals.
For those seeking more control, a basic portfolio of U.S. and international stocks plus investment-grade bonds is sufficient and effective.
For intermediate-term goals (5–10 years), a high-quality bond index fund or low-cost actively managed fund may offer better returns due to stronger performance in this category.
Simplicity reduces decision fatigue, improves portfolio transparency, and makes it easier to pass on to heirs or manage during cognitive impairment.
A simple portfolio enhances financial clarity, helping investors assess whether they are saving enough to meet long-term goals.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article by Jeanne Sahadi for CNN promotes the KISS (Keep It Simple and Smart) investing strategy, arguing that most active fund managers fail to outperform passive index funds. Data from Morningstar shows that only 21% of active funds beat their passive counterparts over a 10-year period, and just 7.1% of large cap blend funds outperformed index funds over 20 years. The article recommends that individuals adopt simple, low-cost portfolios—such as target-date funds or a mix of U.S. and international stocks and bonds—because they reduce decision fatigue, improve financial clarity, and are easier to manage or pass on. It also highlights the psychological and practical benefits of simplicity, especially for older adults or those with cognitive impairments, and emphasizes that strong savings habits are more important than chasing high returns.
title: The benefits of keeping your investing life simple
